evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is a robust explanation for the incident, with no evidence contradicting its role in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal case.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors contributing to operational errors in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal scenario.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.

slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters in the context of Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure fits the key features observed in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal, including timing, crew actions, and environmental conditions.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The lack of warnings and assumptions by crew members indicate communication breakdown rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiencies were primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document lack of communication and coordination among crew during the pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew intentions and possible procedural deviations

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: No mechanical failure was reported or observed in the evidence.
The incident was caused by human factors rather than equipment malfunction.
defeaters: If evidence of verified mechanical faults or bench checks indicating control malfunction were found.
If fault codes or repeat malfunctions were documented.
If physical evidence of mechanical failure was presented.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H8, H12) indicates communication was ongoing and no hardware faults were reported; the tug instructor controlled the pushback and no mechanical failure was noted. The aircraft moved past the TRP due to procedural or communication issues rather than mechanical failure (H4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence; ambiguity whether procedural or communication failures caused the incident.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors contributing to operational errors in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal scenario.

assumptions: Crew communication and coordination are critical human factors in operational errors
No significant mechanical or environmental factors override communication breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviations without communication issues
If mechanical failures or environmental deficiencies were primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 describe communication and coordination failures among crew members, including lack of warnings and assumptions, supporting the claim that communication breakdown aligns with key human factors contributing to operational errors.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew intentions and incomplete communication details

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP described in H7 and H13 corresponds to the environmental or marking deficiency referenced in the claim.
The timing of the evidence corresponds to the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was adequately visible and marked according to standards, or if the collision was solely due to procedural errors without any marking deficiency.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 directly describe the presence and characteristics of the TRP marking relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the prefinal inspection phase, supporting the claim that the environmental or marking deficiency was present and identifiable.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the adequacy and visibility of the TRP marking as perceived by personnel

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.

assumptions: The TRP markings and environment were adequate as per H7 and H13
No mechanical faults were reported or evident
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiencies causing the deviation
If communication was clearly effective and no procedural deviation occurred

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 documents the pushback procedural deviation with the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier. H8, H10, and H12 indicate communication and signaling issues consistent with procedural deviation rather than environmental or mechanical causes, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in communication effectiveness and signaling adequacy

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal, including timing, crew actions, and environmental conditions.

assumptions: Crew actions and timing described are representative of the event
Environmental conditions and markings were as described and visible
No mechanical control failures occurred as no evidence supports this
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or equipment failure causing the pushback beyond TRP
If communication logs indicated clear warnings or coordination breakdowns that explain the deviation
If environmental markings were proven inadequate or invisible to crew

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H9, H10, H12, H13) shows the procedural deviation aligns with key features: timing of pushback past TRP, crew actions including instructor takeover and communication, and environmental conditions such as TRP visibility and marking adequacy. Discriminators favor procedural deviation over communication breakdown, environmental deficiency, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in crew communication and signaling effectiveness; limited direct observation of crew decision-making at the moment of deviation

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is a robust explanation for the incident, with no evidence contradicting its role in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal case.

assumptions: Crew communication and coordination are critical to safe pushback operations
No significant mechanical failure occurred as per evidence
Procedural deviations are distinguishable from communication breakdown based on behavior and signals
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew with no errors
If mechanical faults or procedural deviations were proven to be primary causes
If environmental or marking deficiencies were shown to be the main factor

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 show lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during pushback, supporting the claim that communication breakdown is a robust explanation. No evidence contradicts this role.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew actions and possible unreported factors

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP marking described in H7 and H13 is representative of the actual environmental marking at the time of the incident.
No additional evidence contradicts the adequacy of the environmental or marking deficiency.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were missing, unclear, or inconsistent with standards, or if the crew had clear visibility and understanding of the markings but still failed to stop, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 describe the TRP marking and its small size, supporting that the environmental marking corresponds to key features. However, H8, H10, and H12 indicate communication and procedural issues rather than marking deficiencies, favoring alternative explanations per discriminators.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the marking adequacy or crew procedural/communication failures were primary causes

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP markings and their visibility are critical to identifying environmental or marking deficiencies
Crew communication and signaling methods impact the robustness of deficiency identification
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were clearly visible and unambiguous to all crew members
If communication protocols ensured timely and effective warnings from wingman or headset operator
If procedural compliance was strictly followed without ambiguity

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 directly address the adequacy and visibility of the TRP markings and the communication signals used during pushback, supporting that the environmental or marking deficiency identification was robust against defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in visual signaling effectiveness and small size of TRP

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal context.

assumptions: The statements from the tug instructor, trainee, and headset operator are accurate and complete
No undisclosed environmental or mechanical issues influenced the pushback beyond procedural factors
defeaters: If new evidence showed explicit communication failures or misinterpretations that directly caused the deviation
If environmental or mechanical factors were proven to be primary causes rather than procedural deviation

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate that communication and signaling limitations existed, and the instructor's actions were deliberate and monitored, supporting that the procedural deviation withstands counterarguments related to communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in the adequacy of communication signals and the trainee's assumptions about instructor actions

children_spec.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check maintenance and operational logs for equipment readiness and downtime records during the pushback period

children_spec.statement: Availability of qualified personnel to perform pushback procedures
children_spec.test_procedure: Review staffing rosters and personnel qualifications for the pushback shift

children_spec.statement: Availability of clear and accessible procedural documentation for pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify presence and accessibility of pushback procedural manuals and checklists at the operation site

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure fits the key features observed in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected or reported in the evidence
Procedural and communication factors are sufficient to explain the event
defeaters: If evidence of verified hardware faults or repeat malfunctions were found
If bench checks confirmed control malfunctions
If communication failures were ruled out or no procedural deviations occurred

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H12) shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit the blast barrier despite no reported mechanical faults; communication and procedural issues are highlighted, contradicting mechanical/control failure as the cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence and reliance on procedural and communication observations

node.statement: Availability of qualified personnel to perform pushback procedures

assumptions: Qualification and awareness imply availability to perform pushback procedures
No mechanical or environmental issues caused the deviation
defeaters: If evidence showed personnel were unqualified or unaware of TRP markings
If mechanical faults or environmental deficiencies were documented as primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H9 and H11 confirm the availability of qualified personnel (trainee driver and headset operator) aware of TRP and trained for their roles, supporting the claim of availability of qualified personnel. Discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN favors procedural deviation over communication failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on personnel performance quality or possible unnoticed communication issues

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are physically present at the location
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the location to verify the presence of all required environmental markings

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are visible under current lighting and weather conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess visibility of markings during the relevant time and weather conditions

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are maintained in a legible and unambiguous state
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate the condition and clarity of markings for legibility and ambiguity

node.statement: Availability of clear and accessible procedural documentation for pushback

assumptions: Training and knowledge of TRP imply availability of clear and accessible procedural documentation.
No contradictory evidence about procedural documentation availability is present.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the crew lacked access to or understanding of procedural documentation, or if environmental or mechanical factors were primary causes, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H9, H11, and H13 show that procedural documentation and training about the TRP existed and was known to the crew, supporting availability of clear and accessible procedural documentation for pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about the sufficiency of visual signals and actual procedural adherence, but training and knowledge of TRP are documented.

node.statement: Required environmental markings are maintained in a legible and unambiguous state

assumptions: Markings described in H7 and H13 reflect the condition at the time of inspection
No direct evidence indicates markings were illegible or ambiguous
defeaters: If evidence showed markings were illegible or ambiguous
If crew reported confusion specifically due to marking condition

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 describe the TRP marking and its visibility, indicating the marking was present but small, suggesting markings were maintained but possibly not fully effective, favoring procedural deviation over marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in marking adequacy and visibility

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, communication device records, and physical presence reports to confirm availability

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify maintenance and functionality reports of communication equipment and confirm no outages during the event

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to respond to communication attempts
children_spec.test_procedure: Review medical and incident reports to determine if any crew member was incapacitated or impaired

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were physically absent or unreachable during the operation
If communication devices or signals were non-functional or ignored

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H8, H11, H12, and H13 directly indicate that crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were physically present and reachable during the operation, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none

node.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to respond to communication attempts

assumptions: Active communication and responses imply no incapacitation or inability to respond.
defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were incapacitated or unable to respond to communication attempts, or if communication devices failed.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, H12) shows crew members were alert, communicating, and able to respond, supporting that they were not incapacitated or unable to respond to communication attempts.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statements about incapacitation; inference based on active communication and responses.

node.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members

assumptions: Operational communication devices imply accessibility to all crew members.
No evidence indicates communication device failure or inaccessibility.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication devices were malfunctioning or inaccessible to crew members.
If there were explicit reports of communication failures or inability to access communication channels.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, H11, H12, and H13 show communication devices and channels were operational and accessible, but coordination breakdown occurred due to procedural deviations and assumptions, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew behavior and assumptions despite operational communication devices

node.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation

assumptions: The presence of TRP markings and clearance as described implies availability of required pushback equipment.
The lack of mandatory use of marshalling wands does not imply unavailability of equipment.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were missing or inadequate to the point of being unusable, or that equipment was physically unavailable or malfunctioning, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 directly address the availability and adequacy of pushback equipment and markings, indicating that the TRP was marked but small and that visual signals for stopping were insufficient, supporting the claim of availability of required pushback equipment.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in adequacy and visibility of markings and signals

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters in the context of Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: No direct mechanical fault evidence is present in the provided history
Operator communication and signaling deficiencies are sufficient to explain the event
defeaters: If verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical failure were present
If physical evidence showed control system malfunction
If operator procedural deviations were ruled out

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H10, H12) shows the pushback continued past the TRP due to insufficient visual signaling and operator assumptions, indicating environment/marking deficiency rather than mechanical failure, thus mechanical/control failure is not resistant to defeaters here.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in operator actions and lack of direct mechanical fault evidence

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were obscured or not visible under current lighting and weather conditions, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 indicate the TRP marking exists and is visible, though small, suggesting environmental markings were present and visible, contradicting the claim of deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity about actual visibility and adequacy of markings under operational conditions

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, H12) shows crew members communicated and coordinated during the event, contradicting the claim that communication was unavailable.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the event

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H8, H11, and H12 confirm crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were physically present and accessible during the event, supporting the claim. Discriminators favor communication breakdown over mechanical failure or procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence directly supports physical presence and accessibility of crew
